title: Should I always use 'yet' in questions like 'Have Diane and Paul arrived yet?' Is it a mistake to write 'Have Diane and Paul arrived?' - Quora

response.answer_text: The other answers are correct. However, to keep it simple, Both questions can be used and mean basically the same thing. But - there are nuances of difference: If Diane and Paul have not arrived yet and it has only been a short while since they were expected, someone might ask calmly ‘Have Diane and Paul arrived?’ Later, long after they should have arrived, one might ask in a more strident, disappointed or angry manner ‘Have Diane and Paul arrived yet?,’ with a lot of stress put on the word ‘yet’.

There's no need to always use 'yet' though many do. Yet can be an intensifier - but the sentences ' Have Diane and Paul arrived? and Have Diane and Paul arrived yet? - can mean one and the same thing. Placing the 'yet' on the end might be more a reflection of custom - unless the word 'yet' is said in a different tone - it doesn't change the meaning of the sentence.

Both forms of the question are acceptable. The first version implies that the person who is asking the question is expecting Diane and Paul to arrive very soon or that they are already running late. The second form of the question is more neutral and has no overtones of anxiety, impatience, expectation or worry.

Most decidedly not, depending on the particular circumstance. Are Diane and Paul usually punctual? Have they been very long expected? Are they the Guests of Honour? Is the weather extraordinarily inclement?
I would use “have Diane and Paul arrived” looking around trying to find them.
